response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms a human arm resting on a table surface with the robot end-effector grasping the human's wrist. The human wrist is dislocated, requiring the robot to reposition the wrist bone relative to the arm. The robot gripper is in contact with the wrist area, applying controlled forces and motion to relocate the wrist bone smoothly without causing excessive discomfort or injury. The environment includes a flat table surface underneath the arm and wrist, and the arm is in a somewhat relaxed position.

The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: 
- Red axis (+X) points approximately rightward in the image and world frame, roughly aligned with lateral motion of the wrist along the arm's width.
- Green axis (+Y) points approximately forward into the image workspace, roughly aligned with moving the wrist along the forearm toward or away from the elbow.
- Blue axis (+Z) points approximately upward in the image, roughly corresponding to moving the wrist vertically off the table surface.

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to 
vertical motion upward from the table surface in the world frame (+Z is lifting the wrist off the table, -Z is pressing it down toward the table).

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move 
slightly upward (+Z) to lift the wrist off the table surface as necessary to align the bones.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to 
right-left lateral movement of the wrist relative to the arm forearm axis (+X is moving the wrist to the right in the image/world, -X is leftward).

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move 
moderately toward the correct alignment laterally (likely a slight negative X motion if wrist needs repositioning inward).

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to 
forward-backward motion along the forearm axis (+Y moves the wrist forward away from the elbow, -Y toward the elbow).

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move 
some adjustment may be required toward or away along forearm (+ or -Y) depending on exact dislocation.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved 
a small linear combination of positive Z (lifting), slight negative X (medial adjustment), and small Y motion (forward/back) to reposition the wrist bone correctly in 3D space.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish setting the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist, we must consider the following:

- Object Properties: The wrist and forearm bones, muscle, and flesh tissues have moderate stiffness and compliance. The wrist mass is low (~1-2 kg), but precise controlled forces are critical. The materials are mostly softer tissue with bones inside which resist sudden displacement. Friction between skin and robot gripper pads is moderate to high with soft rubber contact surfaces.

- Environmental Factors: Gravity acts downward; the flat table surface supports the arm, adding reaction forces. The table surface roughness imposes friction and resistance against sliding. The wrist joint has biomechanical restrictions and possible resistive torque at the joint due to ligaments and muscles.

- The relevant object is a human wrist, composed of bone and soft tissue, with mass ~1.5 kg, and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of approximately 0.6 due to rubber grip pads and skin texture.

- The surface of interaction is human skin and flesh, soft and compliant, with a static friction coefficient of 0.4 to 0.6 against rubber-like gripper surfaces.

- Contact Types: The robot maintains a pinch grasp contact on the wrist, ensuring stable grip without slip but gentle enough to avoid excessive pressure.

- Motion Type: The task involves a combination of controlled lifting (+Z axis linear), sliding/translation (small lateral and forward/backward shifts on X and Y), and orientational adjustment (tiny rotations) to realign the wrist.

- Contact Considerations: Continuous grip force along the grasp axis must be maintained through the task to prevent slip, requiring forces to counter gravity and resist any shearing motions along the grasp interface.

- Motion along axes: The robot exerts a combination of linear motions along the wrist frame's X (slight medial-lateral), Y (slight forward/back), and Z (lifting), plus minor rotational adjustments (mainly around X and Y axes) to manipulate the wrist bone back into place.

- Task duration: Given the delicate biological tissue manipulation, the task requires slow, deliberate motions over approximately 5-10 seconds to reposition safely.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Wrist mass ~1.5 kg; gravity force ~1.5 * 9.81 = ~14.7 N downward; friction coefficient about 0.6 between gripper and skin.

- Relevant equations: Friction force = normal force * friction coefficient; required grasp force to prevent slip must overcome tangential forces from motion, gravity, and resistive tissue force.

- Relevant assumptions: The wrist dislocation requires forces just above natural resistance of soft tissue and ligaments without sudden large force spikes; minor torque adjustments can realign bone; robot torque sensors can ensure delicate force control.

- Computations: Minimum grasp force to prevent slip, assuming maximum tangential force ~5 N, grasp must exceed 5 N / 0.6 ≈ 8.3 N; safety margin to 10-15 N grasp force.

- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 1.5 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.6 along the surface: To lift wrist, upward force slightly above 14.7 N (gravity load) is needed, say ~16 N; lateral force needed for sliding less, estimated ~2-3 N; torque to rotate wrist joint small, estimated 1 N-m range.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task and based upon lateral alignment needs and grip friction, the object in the image must exert small negative force along the X-axis with magnitude 3 N (medial correction).

Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task and based upon forward-backward adjustment, the object in the image must exert small positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude 2 N.

Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task and based upon gravity and lifting requirements, the object in the image must exert positive force along the Z-axis with magnitude 16 N.

Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon wrist rotational realignment needs, the object in the image must exert clockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 1 N-m.

Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon wrist subtle pitch adjustment needs, the object in the image must exert counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 0.8 N-m.

Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon minimal twisting of the wrist around forearm axis, the object in the image must exert no significant torque about the Z-axis (0 N-m).

Grasping force:  The grasping force must overcome slip forces and maintain stable contact with the skin, estimated between 10 to 15 N based on friction and mass considerations.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human wrist with approx. 1.5 kg mass, soft tissue and bone, gripper-skin friction ~0.6, delicate compliance and limited joint mobility."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Small lateral negative X motion, small positive Y forward motion, moderate positive Z lifting, with minor rotational adjustments about X (clockwise) and Y (counterclockwise)."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [-0.02, 0.015, 0.05]  # meters; small precise repositioning motions
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [-3.0, 2.0, 16.0, 1.0, -0.8, 0.0]  # forces in N, torques in N-m
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 12.0  # N, midrange secure grasp force
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 8.0  # seconds
```

[end of motion plan]

The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
